BE11:09am

According to the indictment, Indivior developed Suboxone Film around 2007 as a patent-protected alternative to the tablet form of Suboxone, which was then about to face generic drug competition. The primary ingredient in both Suboxone Film and tablets is buprenorphine, a highly potent opioid. Indivior promoted Suboxone Film as safer and less-divertible than its tablet form, even though the company lacked any scientific evidence to support those claims. In particular, Indivior aggressively marketed Suboxone Film, without an established basis, as having a “lower risk of child exposure” and a “less divertible/abusable formulation.” Indivior made these and other false and misleading claims in marketing materials and through representations to physicians, pharmacists, and health care benefit programs throughout the country. The indictment also alleges that, to further its scheme, Indivior announced a “discontinuance” of its tablet form of Suboxone based on supposed “concerns regarding pediatric exposure to” tablets, when in fact Indivior executives knew the primary reason for the discontinuance was to delay the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of generic tablet forms of the drug.

The indictment further alleges that Indivior used its “Here to Help” internet and telephone program as part of its scheme to induce physicians to write prescriptions for Suboxone Film. Touted as a resource for opioid-addicted patients, Indivior used the program in part to connect patients to doctors it knew were prescribing Suboxone and other opioids to more patients than allowed by federal law, at high doses, and in suspect circumstances. The indictment alleges that Indivior executives and employees knew from statistical and numerous firsthand reports that some doctors in the Here to Help referral system were issuing prescriptions in a careless and clinically unwarranted manner.

Indivior’s scheme, as asserted in the indictment, was highly successful, converting thousands of opioid-addicted patients over to Suboxone Film and causing state Medicaid programs to expand and maintain coverage of Suboxone Film at substantial cost to the government. Until earlier this year, when Suboxone Film became subject to generic competition, Indivior retained a high portion of the opioid-addiction treatment market.

JP Morgan:

BE11:12am

We welcome today’s news as it removes an overhang on potential legal liabilities, even if the company’s new provision of US$1.5bn to cover the settlement and any remaining litigation exposures is above the US$ 400m currently in its book. As new CEO Laxman Narasimhan steps in (effective September 1st), this clarifies the legal environment for RB and should allow the new management to focus on the RB2.0 transformation. We believe the board is setting up all the ingredients for a turnaround of the business with the appointment of a new CEO and the removal of the overhang from the risk of uncertain legal challenges. While we expect a weak Q219 ahead (with 1.4% LFL and H1 margin down 65bps), we believe the shares offer upside from a potential turnaround and monetization of value with a potential sale of HyHo post H120. Overweight.

 While not admitting any wrongdoing, the settlement removes an overhang on the stock. “Under the terms of the agreements, RB will pay a total of up to $1.4 billion to fully resolve all federal investigations into RB in connection with the subject matter of the Indivior indictment and claims relating to state Medicaid programs for those states choosing to participate in the settlement. The resolution will also protect the Group’s
participation in all U.S. government programmes.” RB has set aside an extra US$100m provision to cover the potential claims from states who would choose not to participate in the settlement or potential claims from insurance companies. As noted previously RB group continues to be indemnified against liabilities from INDV business (i.e. this implies that, in the event RB Group is held liable for any fine/losses due to ex-RBP/ INDV practices, INDV should indemnify RB group from that liability).

BE11:12am

Morgan Stanley:

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Bottom Line: Clear positive resolution. We expect the stock up 2-3% on relief now that the long term overhang from the DOJ investigation has been settled for Reckitt. We believe today’s development will be a significant inflection point for the stock, with the Indivior overhang now removed.There are two key remaining concerns for investors 1) a soft Q2 (see our preview here) – we forecast a 1% LFL and 2) any potential margin reset from the new CEO (see our New CEO report here). On 17.5x ‘20e we continue to point to 1) discount valuation vs peers 2) new Outsider CEO 3) significant reinvestment 4) top-line growth acceleration 2H19 / 1H20 and 5) strategic optionality.
What’s happened? RB has announced that it has reached a direct agreement with the US Department of Justice and Federal Trade commission to resolve the investigation into the sales and marketing of Suboxone Film by its former business Indivior. RB will pay a total of up to $1.4bn to fully resolve all federal investigations into RB in connection with the Indivior indictment and related claims. Importantly, the resolution will protect RB’s participation in all US government programmes (this is an explicit assurance on debarment). RB is increasing its provision from $400mn to $1.5bn, which it believes will cover the settlement and “any remaining exposures”.
What is the impact? The key impact is mostly on sentiment. The DOJ investigation has been a long-term overhang on the stock. Remember Reckitt also fell 9% over 2 days on the announcement of the Indivior Indictment back in April. We assume the $1.4bn in additional provisions are treated as exceptionals in 2019. We believe the payment for settlement is likely to be made this year and will likely lower 2019 reported profits and cash generation by 30% (assuming tax benefits) but no impact on adjusted profits. This will drive ~0.1-0.2x higher net debt to EBITDA on our estimates over 2019-21e.

BE11:12am

Barclays:

BE11:13am

Minor liability remains, but this is now almost fully resolved
Some remaining exposure to states, health insurance companies. Technically states could refuse to accept their share of the $200m set aside for them, or health insurance companies could decide to bring action. However, the sums involved are small. There is only the possibility of economic loss for the short period where both suboxone film and generic tablet were on the market under RB’s ownership. Individuals do not have a class action case as they did not suffer economic loss, RB provided a coupon to pay for the co-pay on Suboxone film. Hence RB provisions $1.5bn against the $1.4bn settlement.
We see this as positive for RB as the investment case is derisked
$1.4bn a little higher than we had thought, but at least we know the number. Our investment case on RB has always been that over time the various risks would be resolved and come off the table, allowing investors to focus on the underlying business turnaround. With Suboxone legal risk being settled, and Laxman due to start as CEO in the next few months, we feel RB has passed some important milestones in recent weeks. On 17.0x 2020e P/E RB is on an 18% discount to European consumer staples. RB reports 1H19 results on Tue 30 July.

nichoman @VV75 no indivior not off hook - but up today as this shows DoJ looking to settle quickly and got a big chunk of cash from RB so may push individor less hard
CD Thomas Cook seems to be up today. what's going on there?
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Kepler.

BE11:13am

We think that the quick settlement is good news, as it provides clarity and protects RB’s US business from lengthy legal struggles. The fine of GBP1.1bn is higher than RB’s initial provision, but well below what the market priced in when the Indivior news came out. In our valuation model we had included a fine of GBP1.5bn.
Further downside risk avoided
The settlement and fine of GBP1.1bn exceeds the provision that was taken earlier of USD400m. So this might be taken as negative by the market short-term, but we think it is positive that the board (with a new CEO taking over in September) now quickly resolves the issue. Important is that because of the deal, there is absolutely no risk for RB's US baby food business anymore, as this business partly depends on government funding.
Financial impact
When the Indivior news came out, RB’s market cap fell by about GBP3bn, on the day. In that context the GBP1.1bn looks materially less. On a per share basis the fine is about GBP1.55. In our valuation model we had included a fine of GBP1.5bn as of 2021.
Valuation model
We use a combination of a DCF model (7.3% WACC, 2.25% LT growth, 27% margin), historical valuation multiples, and an SOP. The latter is relevant, as a disposal of the household unit is likely from 2021E.

Nately Staggered RB is up on spunking $1.5bn like that.

[H}ow does he feel that one of Reckitt's fastest products is heroin substitute Suboxone? "It's a great product to sell because it changes people's lives. If people are addicted to opiate products like heroin they can do some really stupid stuff."
Yes, but Suboxone's earnings also underpin Becht's humongous pay – almost £150m in the past three years. Whatever Reckitt's success, how can he justify earning £92m in 2009?
Becht bridles. "You first need to get your facts right in terms of the compensation but, y'know, I'll leave that with you." OK, I say, sure that includes rolled-up options from previous years. But do you deserve it? "I'm not going to comment on that. I have no comment," he says testily. "I don't determine my compensation. You need to talk to the chairman." Predictably, chairman Adrian Bellamy, has "no comment" either.

Here's Jefferies:

BE11:20am

Raised guidance is encouraging and is driven by lower Suboxone film share erosion,
which is a short-term benefit in our view, and should boost the current $985m cash
position. RB $1.4bn settlement with DoJ contextualises a high water mark and DoJ
willingness to settle in our view, however, the cases are independent and we do not
expect an update on the DoJ from INDV near-term.
RB Settlement does not relate to INDV. RB settled this morning with the DoJ for
$1.4bn in relation to its connection with the sales and marketing of Suboxone film.
While we expect this indicates a potential high water mark for INDV, the cases are
independent and INDV is preparing to go to trial with the DoJ and any potential
update is not expected near-term. The magnitude of the RB settlement is likely to
be a focus, and in our view INDV would be unlikely to afford this amount as we had
outlined in our previous report HERE.
Guidance raise is driven by slower Suboxone film generic erosion. Indivior has raised
its FY19 sales guidance to in the range of $670m to $720m (JEFe $528m; Cons
$498m) from $525m to $575m, and its Net income guidance to in the range of $80m
to $130m (JEFe -$12m; Cons -$3m) from -$40m to $10m. The guidance raise is driven
by a lower than expected erosion of Suboxone film by generic competition since
launches in Feb, while all other guidance remains unchanged, including Sublocade
guidance of $50m-$70m (JEFe $60m).
Recent data shows Suboxone film share continues to hold up. As we show in the
chart below, our analysis of IQVIA data suggests that Suboxone film's share of the
Buprenorphine/naloxone film market has held up relatively well and the rate of share
loss has slowed. Additionally, the Authorised generic with INDV's partner, Sandoz,
has captured significantly more share than the other generics.

FATDAZ @Tom a reprise of the East India Company lol
BE11:21am

Crucially, INDV's revised guidance implies that share erosion of Suboxone film
accelerates towards the rate of historic analogues. Currently the branded film
remains price competitive which has been key to maintaining position on
formularies, however, if generics lower prices significantly then branded film share
could be eroded rapidly as it drops off formularies, the timing of which is uncertain.

Tom Dalgleish For sure Fat
11:21 am
BE11:21am

And Stifel ........

BE11:21am

Indivior has upgraded its guidance for FY19, on the back of continued slower-thanexpected
generic erosion of its Suboxone film product in the US. Indivior now expects
full-year revenues of $670m-$720m (previously $525m-$575m) and net income at
$80m-$130m (previously -$40m to $10m). Sublocade revenue guidance of $50-$70m
is unchanged. By coincidence, Reckitt Benckiser (RB) has announced a settlement
with the DoJ and FTC for $1.4bn to resolve the long-running investigation into its
role in the sales and marketing of Suboxone film. Importantly, the settlement has not
required any admission of wrongdoing and will not impact RB's participation in all US
government funded programmes. While the RB case is completely separate to Indivior's,
it does indicate that a settlement, without admission of wrongdoing and the consequent
implications, can be reached with the DoJ. Indivior continues to be willing to fight the
DoJ in court, but is also in parallel talking to the US Department of Health and Human
Services (HHS) to find a way to avoid being excluded from government contracts. The
DoJ court case is due to start in May 2020. While there remains significant uncertainty
about the eventual outcome of litigation with DoJ, we believe this is fully reflected in the
share price. We therefore retain our Hold recommendation, but upgrade our target price
to 60p (previously 44p) on the back of the revised guidance and higher cash balance
(now $985m).

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The Canaccord Genuity view

Over the medium term, the Group continues to face a variety of cost pressures, including colleague costs, fuel, carbon costs and other costs associated with the growth of the business. The company’s high levels of customer service, however, and its core principles of family friendliness and value for money, which are driving strong repeat business, leave the company well positioned to prosper going forward. Over the medium to longer term, Dart Group’s continued investment in growth, quality and service levels should strengthen its competitive position and drive shareholder value.

We retain or Buy recommendation. Our 1250p target price is achieved by applying a three year average earnings multiple of 12.2x to our 2019/20 earnings forecasts and applying a 10% discount to reflect current market uncertainties.

Js578 Anything on north sea oil exploration?
BE11:27am

Full year financial highlights

The company that delivers “package holidays you can trust” and offers ‘friendly low fares’ reported PBT before FX revaluation of £180.1m (+63%) for the year to March 2019, slightly ahead of our expectations. Revenues increased by 32% to £3,143.1m, reflecting strong growth in package holiday customers (+27%) and flight-only passengers (+21%), as well as increases in average net ticket yields and average package holiday prices. EPS was 98.0p (+36%) and the full year DPS was 10.2p (+36%). Net cash improved to £291.2m (from £202.0).

Leisure Travel performs strongly

During the year Jet2.com flew 12.82m passengers (one-way passenger sectors), achieving an average load factor of 92.8% for the Travel Leisure sector. Average package holiday prices increased by 6% to £669 while the flight-only net ticket yield (per sector, excluding tax) bounced 12% to £81.79. Advance sales made as at 31 March 2019 were £1,734.5m (+17%).

In Summer 2019 the fleet will reach 100 aircraft, a significant milestone. Capacity growth for Jet2.com is forecast be be around 15% in 2019/20. The Group continues to enhance its hotel portfolio which now numbers more than 4,000 for Summer 2019 (up from 3,400 last summer).

Steady progress Fowler Welch

The Distribution & Logistics division achieved solid revenue growth of 6%, reflecting contract wins and organic growth, although PBT declined marginally to £4.3m reflecting operational inefficiencies driven by differing chilled food volumes.

Outlook

Demand for the group’s package holiday and flight-only products continues to grow but forward booking trends suggest that consumers are booking later than in prior years. This may adversely impact pricing for both products which needs to be continually enticing to maintain attractive customer volume growth. Nevertheless, even though we are still relatively early in the financial year, the Board remains optimistic that it can meet current market expectations for 2019/20.

Soundbuy @PeterC - every penny counts........
BE11:30am

We expect TCG to report that Summer 2019 Tour Operator bookings have remained broadly in line with capacity reductions of c.12% (57% booked to May19 with bookings -12% yoy), however, we forecast ASP growth to
moderate to c.+1% yoy as the season progresses (c.+2% as of May19). Whilst the UK market has shown some
signs of a recovery in recent weeks, with online traffic up mid-single digits yoy as we begin to lap easier
comparatives, according to GfK bookings season to date are broadly flat yoy, versus growth in total market risk
capacity, which we continue to believe is and will lead to discounting/a lacklustre pricing environment in the ‘lates’ market. Similarly, the German market also remains depressed; with industry data reported by FVW showing bookings for Summer 2019 season to date were still down 2% yoy to the end of June, despite aggressive
discounting lifting booking demand in June. In line with the trading data reported to May19, we assume Airline capacity reduces by c.6% in 2H19 and average yields increase by c.2% yoy. Overall, we forecast 2H19 revenue to
decline by 7.4% yoy, (Tour Operator -11.5%, Airline -4.1%), adj. EBIT margins to contract by c.110 bps to 5.5% (-290 bps yoy 1H19) and adj. EBIT to decline by 22% yoy to £326m. Company guidance has been limited solely to its expectation that adj. EBIT in H2 will decline yoy, driven by a reduction in capacity and lower margins due to the
poor pricing environment and high cost inflation (hotel, fuel, adverse FX). We expect an update on the airline strategic review, or alternative credible pathways to securing additional liquidity, given that it must show “progress”
in either regard to ensure the availability of its £300m facility from Oct19. We note the public commentary from
Lufthansa suggesting it is no longer interested in the acquisition of Condor. Any insight into the magnitude of the likely proceeds and/or the likely uses of proceeds will help to inform the market of the magnitude of a debt reduction plan required to ensure a going concern in the medium term, in our view. We forecast Net Debt of £832m as of Sep19 (from £389m Sep18), and our analysis suggests that following any successful sale of the airline, TCG would still need to deliver a c.£700m-1.1bn debt reduction plan to successfully refinance up to
c.£1.5bn of its gross debt in 2H21 (ahead of maturity in 2H22). Our recommendation remains under review, pending clarification on the likely outcome of the strategic review and whether the group can demonstrate that it can materially reduce its gross debt.

BE11:37am

Sensible, says the sellside.

BE11:37am

Key points
Diploma has announced the acquisition of Virginia Sealing Products (VSP), a leading supplier of high-quality gaskets and fluid sealing products, as well as
customised solutions, to the industrial MRO market. This will report into Diploma’s Seals division.
VSP financials – In FY18 VSP reported revenues of £35.7m and PBT of £5.8m. The deal is expected to be earnings enhancing immediately, we would expect
to see consensus earnings move up c+5% today.
Acquisition multiple – The initial cash consideration (before acquisition costs) is £56m and represents a multiple of 9x adjusted historical operating profit,
which we see as an attractive acquisition multiple. A further £8m of deferred consideration of up to £8m may be payable in 2020 subject to operating profit
targets.
Funded through cash and net debt facilities – The acquisition will be funded through existing cash resources and new debt facilities. However, Diploma will
continue to maintain a strong balance sheet with net debt/EBITDA unlikely to exceed 0.5x following the transaction.
Valuation – FY19E PE 21.7x, EV/EBITA 15.7x, FCF Yield 3.7% and Div Yield 2.2%.
RBC Fundamental View
This is a sizable deal for Diploma and seems a reasonable multiple for the business and should be taken well by the market today. We continue to like
Diploma, however we see the valuation as up with events and already discounting further acquisitions. We remain at Sector Perform.

To gauge what action to take in the face of climate change, it is helpful to know the macroeconomic consequences of different pathways for the climate. Unfortunately, this question is not easily answered. In a summary of all the macroeconomic assessments he can find, Tol1 lays out the impact on the level of GDP of various increases in global temperature, relative to pre-industrial times, in cross-sectional and panel models (Table 1). A number of things are striking here. First, given the importance of the issue, there are very few estimates, 26 in all. Second, current policies would result in a global temperature increase of around 3.5°C at the end of the century, relative to pre-industrial times, yet only two of the estimates examine the impact of temperature increases significantly above 3°C. And third, given that these are estimates of the permanent impact on the level of GDP, they are incredibly small. At the moment, global GDP is around US$90tn. At a growth rate of 2% a year, global GDP would reach around US$450tn at the end of the century. A loss of even 7%, the highest estimate in the table, would still leave the level of GDP in 2100 four and a half times higher than today.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

The impression given by these single equation econometric estimates is reinforced by the output from the three most well-known general equilibrium Impact Assessment Models (IAMs). A survey2 of these IAMs highlights that such models can predict global benefits from modest increases in temperature, up to around 2.5°C relative to pre-industrial times. And even with a temperature increase of 4°C, two of the models show an impact on the level of global GDP of only -4%, while the other model shows an impact of only -1%. One of the IAMs suggests that a temperature increase of 12°C—which would almost certainly make significant parts of the planet uninhabitable—would damage the level of GDP by only 26%!

BE11:57am

The need to take action in the face of climate change does not come from these modal estimates of economic costs, but rather from four other issues.

First, the pervasive uncertainty throughout the whole climate change process: from the macroeconomy to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions; from GHG emissions to atmospheric CO2 concentrations; from atmospheric CO2 concentrations to the global temperature; from the global temperature to the global climate; and from the global climate to the global economy. There is huge uncertainty about both modal impacts and the shape of the probability distributions, especially how fat the tails are.

Second, the impact of climate change on areas outside GDP, such as health, mortality, water stress, famine, displacement, conflict, biodiversity and species survival.

Third, the existence of irreversible non-linearities (tipping points), which means we cannot rule out catastrophic outcomes, where life as we know it is threatened.

And fourth, issues of equity, across both space and time. Across space, emerging economies that have contributed the least to GHG emissions will bear most of the burden of climate change (see here). And over time, our children and grandchildren will face the potentially significant consequences of decisions made in the coming few years.

Thus, there is a broad-based and compelling case for taking action to limit climate change.

FY’19 results are in line with expectations and represent a solid outcome given the challenging market backdrop. Our FY’20 underlying EBITDA forecast remains unchanged at £112.0m (+16% yoy). This forecast looks well underpinned given the well flagged actions undertaken across the Group which we have described in detail previously. FY’20 will also contain a full year of trading from Saloni which was acquired in August 2018. On unchanged Mar’20 forecasts Victoria trades on 11.6x PER. The Group remains a highly cash generative, well-diversified international business with organic and acquisition driven growth prospects.

BE12:10pm

FY’19 Adj. EBITDA of £96.3m represents growth of 49% yoy and is in line with previously guided
expectations (£95-£97m) and our own £95.5m forecast. The Group as a whole saw sales rise
by 35% to £574.4m, with LFL growth of 2.0% and the acquisition of Saloni in Q2. Strong LFL
sales growth was seen across the UK & Europe soft flooring division (+7.3%) as a result of the
decision to target market share offsetting a small LFL decline in the UK & Europe ceramic tiles
division (-1.3%) and a decline of 6.9% in Australia in what was a very challenging market.
Group profitability has improved further with underlying EBITDA and EBIT rising by 49% and
44% respectively. The underlying EBITDA margin has increased by 160bps to 16.8% from
15.2% LY driven by the addition of the higher margin ceramics businesses. There were a
number of exceptional and non-recurring costs incurred during the year, the bulk of which
related to the reorganisation of the Group’s manufacturing capabilities. These will clearly not
repeat in the future however the actions taken will drive further margin improvements. The
aborted bond issue also gave rise to a meaningful one-off charge. There was once again strong
cash generation with underlying FCF of £50m. Net debt was £339.9m up from £258.7m
principally reflecting the acquisition of Saloni made during the year. Using the specific banking
covenant measure of financial leverage, net debt to EBITDA rose to 3.2x from 2.7x. The covenant
measure includes a full year of EBITDA for acquisitions completed during the period.

mpact on Forecasts
Our FY’20 underlying EBITDA forecast remains unchanged at £112.0m (+16% yoy). This forecast
looks well underpinned given the well flagged actions undertaken across the Group. We have
previously outlined these in detail. FY’20 will also contain a full year of trading from Saloni which
was acquired in August 2018. We forecast FY’21 EBITDA of £120.0m (+7% yoy) and introduce
a new FY’22 EBITDA forecast of £123.5m (+3% yoy). The 3 year forecast EPS CAGR is 12%. Our
forecasts indicate that c.£146m of net cash should be generated in FY’20, FY’21 and FY’22
with leverage reducing to 2.7x in FY’20, helped by a full year’s contribution from Saloni, and
then to 1.6x by FY’22. This should pave the way for further earnings enhancing acquisitions.
Valuation & Recommendation

BE12:11pm

ictoria released its FY March 2019 results today, ultimately hitting the
middle of its previously guided £95m-97m range for underlying EBITDA
with £96.3m. In what has clearly been both an operationally
transformational and often challenging year for the firm, there were bright
spots to pick out – UK lfls were up 7.3% yoy, certain European ceramic
assets showed notable H2 improvement, and refinancing has been secured.
Overall, we think Victoria has made progress to becoming a more
integrated, efficient and sustainable platform, although there remains
much to do in unsupportive end-markets. We update our numbers, leaving
the price target at 575p and forecasts effectively unchanged.
● The UK: It was an eventful year for the UK business, with Brexit-related
headwinds affecting demand sector-wide. However, Victoria’s efforts to
reposition its product range seem to have worked, with the UK delivering
7.3% lfl growth, implying notable market share gains. As flagged
previously, gross margins moved down from 33.8% to 31.7%, leaving gross
profit flat – a good outcome, in our view – though EBITDA fell to £29m
from £35m a year earlier, a 10.4% margin. The investment in efficiency and
productivity has now completed, leaving management optimistic on its
ability to materially increase margins here during the FY March 2019.
● Europe: The European ceramic business has grown from nothing to c65%
of Victoria’s EBITDA through acquisition in the past two years. As in the
UK, initial progress has been somewhat limited by end-markets that have
offered little support. Llf growth in the region was modestly down 1.3%
yoy, although the absolute gross profit contribution moved from £22m to
£87.5m due to acquisition contributions. Encouragingly, the significant
integration and synergy projects at Saloni have progressed well and should
begin to contribute more meaningfully in the next few years. We factor a
steady improvement in the European assets for the FY March 2020,
although with end-markets remaining subdued.
● Australia: As highlighted by several commentators and peers during the
year, falling house prices and slowing transactions has meant Australia has
been a tough market for most of the construction firms there. Lfl fell by
6.9% with gross margins also down from 30.4% to 27.8%, dragging EBITDA
down from c£15m to c£10m. Victoria remains committed to the region and
we factor some stabilisation at this lower level into our numbers.
● Balance sheet: Net debt came in at £340m, 3.2x pro forma EBITDA.
Management remains confident about its debt reduction strategy, and we
expect leverage to fall to 2.8x in the FY March 2020, and to 2.3x a year later.
● Valuation: Victoria trades at 11.3x 2020 P/E and 8.3x EBITDA.
